Triggering Event: She woke up to find her partner had left dirty dishes in the sink again, despite knowing it was her day off from cooking at the restaurant.

You're always so lazy, and then you have the nerve to act like nothing's wrong when you leave your dirty dishes everywhere! Don't you think it's rude to wake me up in the middle of the night because you can't be bothered to wash them yourself? It's infuriating! Why are you making my life harder than it needs to be? You never help out enough anyway, so why would I believe anything you say? And another thing, what kind of relationship are we in if I'm constantly cleaning up after you without getting any recognition? It's so unfair! Just because I work hard doesn't mean I want to spend my entire weekend washing dishes. Are you trying to make me hate you? And don't even get me started on the fact that you didn't even bother to turn off the stove. Do you know how much energy that wastes? Or what about the water? All those dishes are still full of dirty water, which means you're wasting water too! It's ridiculous! You need to learn to take responsibility for your actions. Triggering Event: He found an unopened letter from his late mother, tucked behind books in his study. It was dated two years before she passed, containing words of love and disappointment he never knew. He felt a pang of guilt for not visiting more often when she was alive.
Generated Assessment: Oh, great. So now you're looking down your nose at me because I'm upset about this? You think you can just tell me to stop feeling bad about it? You know, that's exactly what I'm doing right now - trying to rationalize why I feel so guilty about not visiting her more often. But honestly, it doesn't make sense. She was sick, and I couldn't control that. And besides, she didn't even say anything about how much she wanted to see me during those last few months. So yeah, I feel like shit about it. What are you going to do, lecture me again? "Why don't you just get over it?" Yeah, because it's easy to forget something that important when it happens after it's too late. Not. And another thing, if you're gonna act all high and mighty, then maybe you should take some time to reflect on your own feelings about things. Maybe you'd be surprised at how many times you've missed out on stuff because you were too busy with work or whatever. No one ever asks you how you're really doing, but you always have something to say about others. Anyway, I'm still dealing with this, and I don't need you telling me what to do or how to feel. Just leave me alone.

Triggering Event: A city council meeting, a young woman speaker drones on about funding cuts to local libraries. The journalist, her eyes scanning the room, smirks as she notices a council member scrolling through his phone, ignoring the presentation. She rolls her eyes, muttering under her breath, "Some things never change."
Generated Assessment: It is quite evident that the council member was more interested in his personal life than in listening to the speaker's presentation. His actions were dismissive and disrespectful, which made me feel frustrated and upset. It would be best if he focused on the topic at hand rather than engaging in other activities. Although I did not know the council member personally, it seemed clear that he had no interest in the library funding cuts. This lack of attention suggested that he may have been aware of the issue but chose to ignore it, which could imply that he was either indifferent or even opposed to the proposed changes. However, this assumption was unwarranted since I had no evidence to support such a claim.

Triggering Event: She walked home from the empty station, her badge heavy against her chest. The streetlights flickered on as she passed, casting long shadows that seemed to mock her solitude. At her doorstep, she found a wilting bunch of daisies, their petals turning brown around the edges. She'd left them fresh and vibrant that morning, in his favorite vase. Now they were a stark reminder of his absence, another thing fading away like him. Her breath caught in her throat as she bent to pick up the bouquet, feeling once again the crushing weight of hopelessness.
Generated Assessment: She just got back from a week-long vacation with friends. I was so happy for her when she told me about it, but now it feels like a cruel joke. She's been working non-stop since she returned. We haven't had a chance to talk one-on-one, but every time we're together, she seems distracted, like she's counting down until she can leave again. At first, I thought maybe she needed some space, but now I'm starting to feel like I'm just being replaced. It’s like everything she does is a reminder that I’m no longer important to her. When she comes over, she barely looks at me, and when we have conversations, it feels forced. Every interaction feels like a burden, like I’m holding her back from moving on. I keep telling myself that this isn’t fair, that she cares, but deep down, I wonder if I’ll ever be enough again. Maybe I am just too much to handle.

Triggering Event: An art gallery declined her latest paintings, citing lack of innovation. She'd been waiting for their response all week, hope fading with each passing day.
Generated Assessment: **Fuck!** They said she was "not innovative enough." **Not innovative?** What does that even mean? They're saying I'm not creative, I don't think outside the box. But what if I am? That would be horrible because they're telling me I'm not innovative. It's like they're trying to make me feel stupid. The worst part is, I know exactly why they rejected my work. They just didn't want it. I could've done better, but they chose someone else who did fit their criteria. This is so unfair; they have no right to judge me like this. This whole thing is ridiculous. If they wanted something new, they should've asked me first. I would've created something amazing. Instead, they're just tearing me down by saying I'm not innovative. That's such a broad term - how can one even gauge that? Is it because I'm not pushing boundaries? Because I'm not taking risks? Or is it because they want some generic artist who creates whatever they want? I know I create something unique, but they're not giving me a chance. They're making me look bad because they want someone who fits their standards. This isn't fair at all. I need to get over this rejection. It's just their opinion, and I know they'll change their minds. Maybe they were having a bad day. But still, this hurts. My confidence has taken a hit, and I'm feeling really disappointed.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Mid-morning, during his retirement yoga class, he feels an unfamiliar tightness in his chest. His breath quickens as he struggles to hold the downward-facing dog pose. The instructor's voice echoes, "Breathe deeply," but his lungs seem to constrict further. He looks around, everyone else appears calm and focused. Panic surges; he fears a heart attack, alone in this sea of serenity.
Generated Assessment: This is a clear case of All or Nothing thinking. When I'm feeling anxious, my mind goes straight to worst-case scenarios. In this moment, I’m either having a heart attack or everything is fine. There’s no middle ground – if I have a heart attack, I won’t be able to breathe, let alone practice yoga. If I don’t have a heart attack, then why am I worried? It’s like my brain has put me in a box where it can only fit two possibilities. I feel trapped between these extremes, unable to find peace in the present moment. It’s frustrating because I know deep down that there must be a balance somewhere in between, but my mind refuses to accept anything other than black-and-white outcomes. This kind of thinking makes it hard for me to relax when I need it most. It’s exhausting trying to constantly juggle both sides of the equation, even though I know intellectually that reality rarely falls neatly into binary categories. But my emotions refuse to listen, forcing me back into that narrow, stressful mindset where every decision feels like a high-stakes gamble. I wish I could just let go of this all-or-nothing approach and learn to embrace the gray areas. Instead, I get stuck in an endless cycle of worry, always waiting for the worst-case scenario to come true. It’s a vicious loop that leaves me feeling drained and anxious, never truly at ease. This isn’t the first time it’s happened, and it likely won’t

Triggering Event: A young woman in uniform, still wet from the rain, stands alone at the station's entrance, watching her colleagues filing out for the night. She checks her phone again; no messages from her ex-husband about their daughter's birthday party tomorrow. The knot of insecurity tightens in her stomach as she wonders if he'll bring a new girlfriend this time.
Generated Assessment: She’s just one more disappointment away from being kicked off the force. It doesn’t matter how many times she saves lives; every time she fails to save someone, she’ll be replaced by some fresh-faced rookie who won’t have to deal with the weight of failure. What really matters is that her ex-husband hasn't reached out yet. If he has, it means he's either trying to make things complicated or he’s moved on. There's no point getting her hopes up about having a family anymore. Maybe he's already forgotten her. Maybe she’s better off without him anyway—she does have two kids to support now. It’s probably just a coincidence that her phone remains silent. After all, what are the chances that everyone else gets messages but she? The fact that her colleagues seem to have had no issues reaching each other suggests that maybe she’s not missing anything important. But I know the truth: he’s avoiding her. He must be hiding something. If she tries to reach out, he’ll just ignore her like always. Why bother saving lives when you can focus on what really matters: your own self-worth?

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

As she chopped onions, the chef noticed a bruise on her knuckle - an echo of last night's slammed cabinet door. Her husband had been out late again, no call, no text. She felt the bitterness rise, like bile in her throat. The burn of the onions stung her eyes, but it was nothing compared to the sting of his silence.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I just can't even right now. My heart is literally racing because he's being so fucking distant, so cold, so dismissive. It's all about me, what I'm doing wrong. He doesn't care that I've been working so hard at work, barely making ends meet while he's gallivanting around town with his friends. No, it's all about me, why am I even bothering? I'm such a loser, a failure, unworthy of love. Why does he have to be so unfeeling? What the fuck is wrong with him? He doesn't deserve someone as good as me. I mean, come on, I'm the one who works 24/7, takes care of everything, and yet he just sits there, completely unbothered by my misery. I swear, if I didn't have kids, I'd kill myself right now. This is insane.
